The solace of your steady gaze.

Could tempt this soul to turn away:

I’d trade the wildest, brightest skies.

Were I to lose your gentle eyes.

As sweet as where your laughter lies;
Each waking hour, a living dream,
Each night, your memory my prize.

Let sailors roam the boundless sea;

My voice a whimper, tightly curled.

I licked the boots of passing days,
Tasted only bitter stones,
But in the cracks of broken praise
A stubborn wildflower had grown.

Now I cast off my battered shell,
Stretch tall my fragile wings,
The ground no longer holds my cell—
Above, a new horizon sings.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I claim the sky.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Pressed flat against the mud of need,
Dreams dissolving in the dunce
Of days that would not let me lead.

I whispered wishes, hid my face,
Let others shape my shrinking form,
Clung to the crumbs of borrowed grace,
Sheltered from every coming storm.

But now, with trembling, upright frame,
I meet the morning’s golden edge—
No longer hiding from the flame,
I rise above the trembling ledge.

I was a grovelling creature once—
Now I drink deep from courage’s fount.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Lowly, silent, unseen,
Dragging the weight of ancient months
Across a canvas painted green.

The earth pressed heavy on my back,
Roots tangled near my heart,
I learned the patience of the black
Soil, and the will to start.

One day, the rain became a song,
The sun a gentle call,
I found the place where I belonged—
Rising, despite it all.

I was a grovelling creature once:
Now I bloom, and do not fall.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Curled in the hollow of despair,
Every hope a distant sconce

Let shame become my only friend,

There is a limit to how much you bend.

So now I stretch, I stand, I roar,
Shed the dust that clung so tight,
No longer pressed to the forest floor—
My soul ascends in flight.

I was a grovelling creature once;
Now, I am the morning light.
